text:
DOUGLAS LAUFFENBURGER: Really,
what we're trying to do

is understand, in terms
of engineering principles,

how living systems work,
how genes regulate function

of cells and tissues
and organisms,

how the proteins
operate, how organisms

decide how to respond to
stimuli in their environment.

And not only understand
biology, but then
to harness it and manipulate it.

Can we use biological components
to build better materials,

materials that are safer for
the environment, drugs that

are safer, drugs
that are cheaper,
drugs that are more effective?

Instead of using things
that we knew about physics

and chemistry over
the last century,

can we now use things
that we know about biology

that we've learned the
last 10 or 20 years?

What we're ultimately
after is the design

of better anti-cancer
drugs, breast cancer,
in this particular case.

What Lisa is working on
is some genetic problems

that would go wrong
in breast cancer.

How do they lead to aberrant
movement of breast cells

into places that they're
not supposed to be,
tumor invasion metastasis?

What is responsible for that at
an underlying molecular level?

And therefore, how could
you intervene at that level
with a more effective drug?

These are cells that we
can grow in the laboratory.

And then we're interested
in their migration behavior

and are they migrating
normally, or are they

migrating more aggressively
than they should be,

because there can
be a problem in one

of the key molecular
regulators or switches

that when there's too much of
it, you have extra gene copies

or it's hyperactive, that
the cells essentially turned

themselves on and stimulate
themselves to proliferate

and migrate, whereas normal
cells need to wait for that

switch to be turned on by
some other appropriate signal.

In the movie, what you're seeing
are human breast tumor cells
under the microscope.

We're measuring how
fast they're moving,

what direction
they're moving in,

are they moving erratically,
because the characteristic

of a tumor cell might be it
moves much faster than it

should and much more
erratically than it should

so that it ends up
in the wrong places.

So what we're trying to
do is find a way for them

to disregard their
self-produced signal,

and therefore, only
listen to signals

that are appropriate from
the tissue around them.

In terms of how
this is progressing,

we have collaborations,
for instance,

with a number of
pharmaceutical companies

who are even now using some
of the results of what we're

doing to improve drugs in
their pipeline to design
their clinical trials better.

That's one thing that
MIT is all about,

is taking what we're
studying in the laboratory

and connecting it to
real societal problems,

whether they're today's problems
or problems that can be solved
10 years from now.

In this particular case, we're
very excited about the fact

that we are working with
some pharmaceutical companies

and what we are doing in
the laboratory is helping

guide the decisions they make
about what drugs they think
will be effective.

Biology is complex,
and they're realizing

that what we're learning about
it as engineers is really

helping them out
some of the problems

that they're encountering in
drug design and development.
